title: The Happiest Notebooks on Earth
text:
What is a notebook?


Mike Bostock:


‚Äúan interactive, editable document defined by code. It‚Äôs a computer program, but one that‚Äôs designed to be easier to read and write by humans.‚Äù


Martin Fowler:


‚ÄúA computational notebook is an environment for writing a prose document that allows the author to embed code which can be easily executed with the results also incorporated into the document.‚Äù

title: The Happiest Notebooks on Earth
text:
One kind of notebook
---
title: "ggplot2 demo"
author: "Norah Jones"
date: "5/22/2021"
format: 
  html:
    fig-width: 8
    fig-height: 4
    code-fold: true
---

## Air Quality

@fig-airquality further explores the impact of temperature on ozone level.

```{r}
#| label: fig-airquality
#| fig-cap: Temperature and ozone level.
#| warning: false
library(ggplot2)
ggplot(airquality, aes(Temp, Ozone)) + 
  geom_point() + 
  geom_smooth(method = "loess"
)
```

title: The Happiest Notebooks on Earth
text:
Why make a notebook?

For communicating to decision makers, who want to focus on the conclusions, not the code behind the analysis.
For collaborating with other data scientists (including future you!), who are interested in both your conclusions, and how you reached them (i.e.¬†the code).
As an environment in which to do data science, as a modern day lab notebook where you can capture not only what you did, but also what you were thinking.

title: The Happiest Notebooks on Earth
text:
Principle #1


Suspended reality

title: The Happiest Notebooks on Earth
text:
Principle #1: Suspended reality


Problem: Walt Disney found it jarring to see characters out of place. It breaks the suspension of reality.
Solution: Disney built the utilidor system ‚Äî a system of some of the world‚Äôs largest utility tunnels
An intricate web of tunnels lies underneath the park, enabling characters to navigate to their respective ‚Äúworlds‚Äù without ever appearing out of world or duplicative.

title: The Happiest Notebooks on Earth
text:
Notebook utilidors


Less magic, more plain text logic

Configuration settings - often YAML in the document header or an external file - preferably define own variables
Outsource a script or document
Reuse code chunks in different places
Conditional evaluation of code







An example




Still from Fantasia (1940), ¬© Walt Disney / Courtesy Everett Collection

title: The Happiest Notebooks on Earth
text:
Principle #2


Multisensory experience

title: The Happiest Notebooks on Earth
text:
Principle #2: Multisensory experience


Problem: Being at Disney World needs to be an immersive, memorable experience.
Solution: Disney built the smellitizer system ‚Äî a system that blows air across scented substances to make the air smell a certain (ideally good) way.

title: The Happiest Notebooks on Earth
text:
Notebook smells


Have you ever seen a notebook with‚Ä¶

No meaningful headings (or worse, cute or peppy ones)
No meaningful heading hierarchy
No navigation
No description of the data
No logical order

title: The Happiest Notebooks on Earth
text:
Notebooks do have a scent


‚ÄúInformation foraging explains how users behave on the web and why they click certain links and not others.

Information scent can be used to analyze how people assess a link and the page context surrounding the link to judge what‚Äôs on the other end of the link.‚Äù






https://www.nngroup.com/articles/information-scent/

title: The Happiest Notebooks on Earth
text:
Smells like a good notebook ü•û



Add a clickable table of contents üìå
Add useful headings

Aim for H2 and H3 levels only
Use sentence case

Limit to five or six H2 sections max if you can
Have a topic sentence
Describe your data (5w+1H)
Lay things out in a logical order

Beginning > middle > end
Logical != chronological

title: The Happiest Notebooks on Earth
text:
Principle #3


Details matter

title: The Happiest Notebooks on Earth
text:
Principle #3: Details matter


Problem: When a single detail is wrong, you lose the experience and the magic.
Solution: Reduce the chances of losing the magic.
Examples:

1. You cannot buy gum
2. Official no-fly zone
3. Always within 30 steps of a trash can

title: The Happiest Notebooks on Earth
text:
Easy things should be easy



Easy styling

Authors want fonts & colors!
Readers want fonts & colors!

Easy layouts

Basic grid with rows/columns

Easy show/hide code and results in output
Easy ‚Äúrun from the top‚Äù mode
Easy way to skip or freeze a code chunk

title: The Happiest Notebooks on Earth
text:
Hard things should be possible



Version control
Export/download source file
Save all plots as image files
Extract all of my code into a script
Reproducible environments

title: The Happiest Notebooks on Earth
text:
Principle #4


Make it shareable

title: The Happiest Notebooks on Earth
text:
Principle #4: Make it shareable




Problem: Making something shareable makes it more memorable.
Solution: Make it easier to share.
Examples:
‚ÄúThe concrete‚Äîa brainchild of Disney and Kodak‚Äîcreates more vivid photographs‚Ä¶and also makes the green grass appear greener.‚Äù
‚Äú[Cinderella‚Äôs] castle faces south, meaning the sun is never directly behind it. It‚Äôs (almost) impossible to take a bad photo of yourself in front of Cinderella‚Äôs Castle.‚Äù

Outtakes, bloopers, and in-between things


Authors should be able to:


Quickly share incomplete thoughts (with errors in code!)
Time travel to different versions (with output!)
Stash bits of code out of sight (with utilidors!)
Annotate easily what to look at and what not to look at üö•

title: The Happiest Notebooks on Earth
text:
Summary
Notebook users should be able to follow all four of these key principles with tools we make for them:

Suspended reality ‚Äî use utilidors to save their sanity and their code



Multisensory experience ‚Äî use navigation and organization to make notebooks smell better to everyone




Details matter ‚Äî ‚ÄúEasy things should be easy, and hard things should be possible‚Äù (Larry Wall)




Make it shareable ‚Äî especially things that don‚Äôt work and things that aren‚Äôt done
